What is a valid argument and an invalid argument in logic?

A valid argument is one where if the premises are true, then the conclusion must also be true; an invalid argument is one where the truth of the premises does not guarantee the truth of the conclusion.

Thus, the explanation of why this argument is invalid is that the sixth row of the table shows a scenario in which the premises are both true and yet the conclusion is false. A v B 2. ∴ A ⋅ B  7. 1. ~(A ⋅ B) 2. ∴ ~A v ~B  8. 1. ~(A v B) 2. ∴ ~A v ~B   9. 1. (R v S) ⋅ ~D 2. ~R 3.
